ygData.subject: Open Question Re: Implementation of Recessive Genes In NEAT Genome
ygData.msgSnippet: There has been work with GAs that have diploid genomes but no work specifically with NEAT that I know of. Here s a general GA paper on the subject:

There has been work with GAs that have diploid genomes but no work 
specifi=
cally with NEAT that I know of.  

Here's a general GA paper on the subject=
:

http://www.springerlink.com/content/7g357l693623837x/

ken

--- In neat@=
yahoogroups.com, "afcarl2" <a.carl@...> wrote:
>
> Derek,
> 
> What prompts=
 my question is an experiment which employs a local 
> gradient search, uti=
lizing the organism output vector as the start 
> point. The result is usua=
lly a higher fitness vector than the 
> original organism output vector fit=
ness.
> 
> One interpretation is to view the implementation as a transform =
of 
> the solution space (i.e. finding the best starting point which 
leads=
 
> to the best fitness). Pairing the local optimal fitness to the 
> organ=
ism rather than the fitness associated with the organism 
output 
> vector.=

> 
> Another possibility is to re-write the organism genome such that 
the=
 
> local optimal vector is it's new output, and assigning the local 
> opt=
imal fitness to the new substituted organism. But the problems 
of 
> speci=
es membership and gene markers are lost.
> 
> Thus the possibility of embed=
ding the local optimal genome as the 
> recessive gene of the original orga=
nism, would allow the species 
> membership and gene markers to remain. At =
least until the current 
> population has been evaluated.
> 
> Have you hea=
rd of any work involving re-writing the organism 
genome 
> during the eval=
uation phase?
> 
> Thanks,
> Andy
> 
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Der=
ek James" <djames@> wrote:
> >
> > Andy,
> > 
> > Not that I know of...mayb=
e Ken knows of NEAT implementations of 
> recessive genes.
> > 
> > At one =
point with ANJI, we discussed going down this route. Since
> > genes in NEA=
T are traditionally monoploid (having only one set of
> > genes), but we th=
ought about doing a diploid representation (two 
> sets
> > of genes, one f=
rom each parent). You could then use 
> dominant/recessive
> > markers for =
genes to determine which ones are expressed. You 
could
> > also experiment=
 with blending, for example in connection weights,
> > where there is neith=
er a recessive nor dominant expression, but 
some
> > blended function of t=
he two (e.g. an average of the two). And if 
you
> > wanted to get really w=
eird, you could implement polyploidy, 
where 
> each
> > individual has any=
 number of sets of genes (e.g. each individual 
> could
> > have 10 parents=
).
> > 
> > I'd be interested to see some data from a direct comparison of =
an
> > implementation with and without recessive genes, so if you're 
going=
 
> to
> > do it, let us know.
> > 
> > --Derek

n a

as 
a
